'Domestic violence', also known as 'domestic abuse', 'spousal abuse',
'battering', 'family violence', 'dating abuse', and 'intimate partner violence
(IPV)', is a pattern of behavior which involves the abuse by one partner against
another in an intimate relationship such as marriage, cohabitation, dating or
within the family. Shipway (2004) Domestic violence can
take many forms, including physical aggression or assault (hitting, kicking,
biting, shoving, restraining, slapping, throwing objects, battery), or threats
thereof; sexual abuse; emotional abuse; controlling or domineering;
intimidation; stalking; passive/covert abuse (e.g., neglect); and economic
deprivation.

Alcohol consumption and mental illness can be co-morbid with abuse, and present additional
challenges in eliminating domestic violence. Awareness, perception, definition
and documentation of domestic violence differs widely from country to country,
and from era to era.

Domestic violence and abuse is not limited to obvious physical violence.
Domestic violence can also mean endangerment, criminal coercion, kidnapping,
unlawful imprisonment, trespassing, harassment, and stalking.

Laws on domestic violence vary by country. While it is generally outlawed in the
Western World, this is not the case in many developing countries. For instance,
in 2010, the United Arab Emirates's Supreme Court ruled that a man has the right
to physically discipline his wife and children as long as he does not leave
physical marks. [http://articles.cnn.com/2010-10-
19/world/uae.court.ruling_1_islamic-law-sharia-law-ruling?_s=PM:WORLD UAE Court
Ruling] The social acceptability of domestic violence also differs by
country. While in most developed countries domestic violence is considered
unacceptable by most people, in many regions of the world the views are
different: according to a UNICEF survey, the percentage of women aged 15â49 who
think that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife under certain
circumstances is, for example: 90% in Afghanistan and Jordan, 87% in Mali, 86%
in Guinea and Timor-Leste, 81% in Laos, 80% in Central African
Republic. http://www.childinfo.org/attitudes_data.php Refusing to
submit to a husband's wishes is a common reason given for justification of
violence in developing countries: for instance 62.4% of women in Tajikistan
justify wife beating if the wife goes out without telling the husband; 68% if
she argues with him; 47.9% if she refuses to have sex with him. http://www.-
childinfo.org/files/MICS3_Tajikistan_FinalReport_2005_Eng.pdf

Traditionally, in most cultures, men had a legal right to use violence to
"discipline" their wives; although in the US and many European countries this
right was removed from them in the late 19th century/early 20th century, before
the 1970s criminal arrests were very rare (occurring only in cases of extreme
violence); and it was only in the 1990s that serious efforts and rigorous
enforcement of laws had became standard policy in Western countries. http:/-
/www.uam.es/personal_pdi/economicas/gmeil/ingles/publicaciones/unece.pdf http://academia.edu/992154/The_Paradoxical_Approach_to_Intimate_Partner_Vio-
lence_in_Finland
headings: Specific forms in parts of the world
